rules.natural: Whenever the video game is developed, it requires materials.
The video game being profitable follows from it using a graphics engine.
The video game uses a graphics engine if it has art assets.
The video game has art assets provided that it purchased licenses.
In the case that the video game is crowdfunded, if the game engine is optimized, then it runs smoothly.
The video game is either venture capital backed or crowdfunded.
The video game having a successful Kickstarter implies it has secured funding.
The video game having secured funding leads to development being stalled if it is not the case that an investor pulls out or it is not venture capital backed.
If the game demo is tested, then it is playable.
The game demo is either tested or showcased.
If the game demo is approved by the publisher, then whenever it is showcased and the game engine is buggy, the game engine crashes.
The game demo is either approved by the publisher or rejected by the publisher.
In the case that the game demo is rejected by the publisher, then if it is showcased and the game engine is buggy, the game engine crashes.
If it is not the case that requiring materials implies purchased licenses for the video game, then the video game infringes copyright.
If it is not the case that an investor pulls out or it is not venture capital backed, then development of the video game is not stalled.
In the event that it is not the case that optimized implies runs smoothly for the game engine, the game engine is buggy.
If it is not the case that not requiring materials implies purchased licenses leads to not infringing copyright for the video game, then a lawsuit is filed against the video game.
Whenever the video game is not profitable, the game engine is optimized.

It is not the case that an investor pulls out of the video game.
It is not the case that the game engine crashes.
It is not the case that the game demo is playable.
